flags.title: User-Contributed Project
flags.text: This project guide is not managed by MAKE staff.

guide.introduction_rendered:
Relevant parts
  • Copper wire
  • LED
  • 20nf capacitor
  • 16v ac power source
Tools
  • Solder
  • Soldering iron

lines.text: The first thing is to make the big coil. You can do this by putting four nails into a board and wrapping the copper wire around them.
lines.text_raw: The first thing is to make the big coil. You can do this by putting four nails into a board and wrapping the copper wire around them.

lines.text: Then you  have to make the smaller coil. It has to be about half the size of the bigger one. You need to put an LED/bulb and a capacitor on the output. I put 2 because I didn't have one that had the right value. You could also put a bridge rectifier on it to turn the AC into DC.
lines.text_raw: Then you  have to make the smaller coil. It has to be about half the size of the bigger one. You need to put an LED/bulb and a capacitor on the output. I put 2 because I didn't have one that had the right value. You could also put a bridge rectifier on it to turn the AC into DC.

lines.text: Connect the power to the big coil and put the small one in the middle and the LED should light up.
lines.text_raw: Connect the power to the big coil and put the small one in the middle and the LED should light up.

lines.text: I tested different gauge wire and the maximum efficiently I got was 42.2%.
lines.text_raw: I tested different gauge wire and the maximum efficiently I got was 42.2%.

guide.title: Wireless Power Transfer
